text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
HET FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- New Dutch cartel authority to fall under economic affairs ministry during first few years of operation, becoming independent after three to five years. (p1)
- ABN Amro Bank says banks will book their soon to be disclosed hidden reserves in different ways. (p1)
- New pay and conditions accord for Dutch metal engineering sector emerged after fifth round of talks. (p1)
- Koninklijke Bijenkorf KBB subsidiary Hema in talks with Belgium's GIB Group on acquiring textiles store chain Sarma. (p3)
- Royal Dutch/Shell's U.S. unit Shell Oil shows rapid earnings growth in 1996 fourth quarter, boosting full-year earnings to 3.7 billion guilders. (p3)
- Free Record Shop is to step up restructuring of its Belgian activities. (p3)
- Nutreco (animal products, breeding farms) forges alliance with Yamaha Motor to gain foothold in Japanese fish breeding and feed market. (p3)
- Dutch retail sales pick up by 4.4 pct year-on-year in November. (p5)
DE VOLKSKRANT
- Incoming European Monetary Institute president Wim Duisenberg slams French proposals to allow elected politicians to have some say over policy of a future European Central Bank. (p1)
- Economic Affairs minister Hans Wijers bans accountants' association collective advertising campaign in a move seen as creating a precedent for other professional bodies. (p2)
- The role played by insurance sector regulator Verzekeringskamer will be reviewed as part of inquiry into collapse of Dutch insurer Vie d'Or. (p2)
- Tour coach maker Den Oudsten and its U.S. partner New Flyer Industries win major U.S. order worth some 60 million guilders. (p17)
DE TELEGRAAF
- Regional bus operator VSN reports passenger numbers up by five percent in 1996 after years of decline. (p7)
- Dutch carrier KLM's U.S. partner Northwest Airlines books record of $ 536.1 million guilders. (p19)
- Employers' association VNO-NCW sharply criticises dutch government's international tax policy. (p19)
- Amsterdam Stock Exchanges again loses case against food group CSM over bourse-listing agreement. (p19)
TROUW
- Dutch newspapers boost 1996 earnings mainly through higher advertising income. (p7)
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- Chemicals concern Akzo Nobel to slash jobs in its fibre division. (p10)
- ABN Amrobank's Asset Management grows 39 percent to 117 billion guilders in 1996. (p10)
